title: New Skins on PBE are WoW themed?
body:
EDIT:
"Exploring dungeons and fighting dragons are all part of the everyday lives of these merry band of men! Join the group on their quest across Runeterra and pick up some sweet loot! " -Nurse Flan
Looks like its just a coincidence, they are 750RP themed group, and Elderwood Hecarim is not part of it.

A lot of new skins have surfaced on the PBE, with several having their names with a surname similar to the format of characters from World of Warcraft, specifically on the Alliance side.

http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Ka3vymBR1u0/VkKHqdir5AI/AAAAAAAA0Po/WWxmUsHhCjQ/s640/varr.jpg 
New Varus Skin looks pretty similar to a Night Elf to me. Its called 'Varus Swiftbolt'

You've got Dwarven Gragas Caskbreaker
http://3.bp.blogspot.com/--qnHEi45D3w/VkKE68UZ1TI/AAAAAAAA0Ow/Ed5JILVcMDE/s640/gragas.jpg
 Human Braum Lionheart
http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-6xCVKPlC43Q/VkKE8IIvl9I/AAAAAAAA0O4/FRHHE1V3DzU/s640/braum.jpg
Cenarius follower Hecarim (note: only one without a last name, titled 'Elderwood Hecarim')
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-vy1KtSbkk6k/VkKFPPQ912I/AAAAAAAA0PA/TfYYhKmOayY/s640/hecarim.jpg
 Ryze Whitebeard's staff and staff on back are both modelled quite similar to weapons in WoW as well.
http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-HZs-5aJjJdk/VkKJBcWqNEI/AAAAAAAA0P8/OKpdbq-KH4I/s640/eyze.jpg


 I'm very intrigued to see if this in an intentional relationship. Partnership with Blizzard? Just a hat-tip towards them? Coincidence?

What do you think?

replies.body:
The skins are most likely a reference to typical fantasy/medieval-characters.
Ryze is your clasical mage
Gragas is....well a caskbreaker
Braum is a knight with a shield
Varus is an archer.

I doubt that elderwood hecarim is part of that skin line considering that there is already a different elderwood skin with elderwood bard.

I wonder if another skin is coming to this medieval-themed skin line as we are still missing a mid/top/jungler(as ryze and gragas could cover 2 of those roles) and they'll add the 5th one later(similar to how malphite was added to the slaughter-crew later on),or maybe an existing skin will fit into this skin-line,like the little-knight amumu(similar to what they did with the card-themed skins) or if they'll simply leave it at 4 champs(like the academy skins)

JRR Tolkien's Middle Earth is definitely a lot closer to the source of modern-day fantasy. Nordic & Greek Mythology -> Middle Earth -> Warhammer -> Warcraft -> DotA -> LoL, the chain of inspiration is eternal.

To be honest I don't think LoL fit's into that chain very well. (which can be seen as a good thing)

The Gameplay comes almost straight from DotA, but the world and characters are really unique and quite a bit removed from traditional fantasy (medieval setting, Elves, Dwarfes, Orcs etc)

That's true and definitely one of the big reasons I wanted to work on this IP. In LoL there are amazing locations from Bildgewater to Piltover that have the expanse and freedom to incorporate all manner of curiosity. It's still a fantasy game though!

To be fair D&D (the skin's base) was originally inspired entirely on Tolkien's world.

The Ryze skin is Elminster, who was at first a Gandalf clone.

And as Kindlejack very wisely puts it:

>The chain of inspiration is eternal.

Or as I like to say:

Nothing is ever 100% original because of Tropes, but we can mix and max tropes as much as we want to make something new.

I think the answer is yes and no.

No, they are based on a fantasy world based on magic, medieval times, and different races.

However, the game that really popularized this kind of fantasy is WOW, so in a way, yes (sorry if there are earlier games that did this).

Edit: A good analogy for this is that if something was based on a post-apocalyptic waste land with bright yet grim characters, it was based off of Fallout.
The game that REALLY popularized this kind of fantasy is Dungeons & Dragons...
